title-group.article-title: Association of Smokeless Tobacco Use with Incident Peripheral Artery Disease: Results from the Atherosclerotic Risk in Communities Study

contrib.aff: Division of Cardiovascular Medicine, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Jeremy Van’t Hof, Division of Cardiovascular Medicine, University of Minnesota, 420 Delaware St SE, MMC 508, Minneapolis, MN 55455, vanth008@umn.edu, Fax number: 612-626-4411, Cell phone: 507-227-4445

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cigarette smoking is associated with increased risk for peripheral artery disease (PAD). It is unknown if smokeless tobacco, a non-combustible form of tobacco exposure, is also associated with increased PAD risk. Using data from the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) study we tested the hypothesis that use of smokeless tobacco is associated with higher risk of developing PAD.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Participants with PAD at baseline were excluded. Smokeless tobacco use was assessed 3 times from 1987–1995, and PAD events accrued from 1987 to 2018. Smokeless tobacco was modeled as a time-dependent exposure in Cox regression models. Analyses were completed in 2021.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: This study included 14,344 participants with a baseline mean (SD) age of 54.1 (5.7) years; 54.8% were female and 26.4% were Black. There were 635 incident PAD events over a median follow up of 27.6 years (maximum 32.1 years). The PAD incidence rate was 4.44 per 1,000 person-years among those who used smokeless tobacco compared to 1.74 per 1,000 person-years for those who did not. The hazard ratio for current versus never smokeless tobacco use was 1.94 (95% CI 1.31, 2.88) after adjustment for sociodemographic characteristics and cigarette smoking. PAD incidence rate among those with current smokeless tobacco use was similar to that of those who currently smoke cigarette (3.39 per 1,000 person-years).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Current smokeless tobacco use was associated with high rates of PAD, similar to cigarette smoking. Future research should evaluate the effect of cessation of non-combustible tobacco on incident PAD.
